title: Erdős Problem #48: φ(n) = σ(m)
description: Are there infinitely many integers n, m such that φ(n) = σ(m)?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #48 asks whether there are infinitely many pairs (n,m) where Euler's totient φ(n) equals the sum of divisors σ(m). This was proved by Ford, Luca, and Pomerance in 2010 using analytic number theory.
overview.problemStatement: Are there infinitely many integers $n, m$ such that $\varphi(n) = \sigma(m)$?
overview.proofStrategy: The proof uses deep results about the distribution of values of arithmetic functions. We formalize the statement and verify concrete examples like φ(5) = σ(3) = 4.
keyInsights: The answer is YES - infinitely many such pairs exist
Example: φ(5) = 4 = σ(3) since divisors of 3 are {1,3}
The full proof requires analytic methods beyond current Mathlib

conclusion.summary: We formalize Erdős Problem #48 and verify the statement with concrete examples. The main theorem is stated as an axiom since the full proof requires analytic number theory.
conclusion.implications: This connects two fundamental arithmetic functions (totient and sum of divisors) in an unexpected way.
